title: How to Bake Roman Officers' Bread

steps.headline: Mix the dough ingredients in a mixing bowl.
steps.description: Mix by hand, using a wire whisk.

steps.headline: Start to make the fermentation liquid.
steps.description: Use a resealable glass/container with a volume of 350 mL (about 1 1/2 cups).

steps.headline: Add lukewarm water to a separate bowl.
steps.description: Add the amount of fresh yeast (or instant yeast) suitable for 250 g flour. Dissolve this together with add two heaped teaspoons full of sugar (the original sweetener was honey, as sugar was unknown in Roman times).

steps.headline: Add the liquid to the flour mix and stir.
steps.description: You can use a kneading hook, preferably with a kitchen mixing machine, for about five minutes. Or, this can be done by hand.

steps.headline: Allow the dough to ferment for one to two hours, covered in a bowl with a kitchen towel.
Do handwork.
steps.description: Knead and treat the dough on a kitchen plank, covered with flour, to avoid having the dough stick on your hands.

steps.headline: Divide the roll-shaped dough into two pieces.
steps.description: Each piece will form one whole bread.

steps.headline: Take two flat oven pans, covered with baking paper.
steps.description: Place in the oven and bake for about 30 minutes at 175°C (about 350°F). Baking time is when using a fan oven.
